author: gioyik
content: Hello, my name is Giovanny and I applied to the Core Development program. Glad to see initiatives like this one, find communities willing to help people learn and get involved into the protocol development. I'll be exploring the discord and channels in the meantime, have learned already a ton of things just by poking around inside conversation threads. Cheers!

author: newweiv
content: I'm really intereseted in applying to this but I don't know too much about core dev...what are some resources I can learn to learn more about the core protocol? I've recently started learning about dapps and smart contracts, but I understand that's not core stuff. I started out learning about bitcoin blockchain, and how blockchain tech works, but where can I learn more about eth protocol? (i've read white paper and started yellow) what does the eth protocol consist of?

author: dock_boss
content: <@755612893046636585>  check the pins in the channel.

author: newweiv
content: thanks doc

content:

author: trent_vanepps
content: great resource, thanks for putting this together!

author: muhdraffiq
content: I am planning to apply but I have yet to figure out which topics in mind or decided on the projects proposed in the github repo. will it be Ok if I apply first and let you know in this channel? or will it be a big part of the application

author: pipermerriam
content: You don't need to know what you want to work on prior to applying, so go ahead and get your application in

author: pipermerriam
content: Seconding the appreciation for putting this together and sharing it.  If you're feeling bold, feel free to PR anything into the `cohort-zero` repository that isn't already there.

author: ogenev
content: Hello, my name is Ognyan, I have ~3 years experience with software engineering. I have been working mainly with Python, Ruby and Clojure, experimenting with Rust too. Crypto holder since 2017. Recently I started to learn more about the blockchain ecosystem and tooling, I would love to dive deep into Ethereum protocol and have some fun.

author: odyslam
content: Hello everyone, I am odysseas, currently leading DevRel at Netdata. I had an intermittent relationship with the blockchain space since 2018,  but after reading "The Sovereign Individual", I am certain that this is the space I want to contribute into. Right now, I am mostly interested in L2 scaling, MEV and generally how changes in the protocol can affect the mechanism design / crypto economics.

author: odyslam
content: I started learning Soildity recently and I am compiling a handful of resources. Although not directly relevant to protocol design/implementation, you might be interested ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è https://dev.to/odyslam/learning-solidity-in-public-58a3

author: odyslam
content: Hey <@!364458974906548225> I have a couple of resources that are *somewhat* related to protocol, such as blog posts about scaling, MEV, etc. Would they be appropriate for a PR? Like populate suggested reading for individual areas that could possibly interest others.

author: akh4880
content: I just added some subsections in the recommended read me you can check out. I think scaling fits in. But you can always add them in your own notes file if it isn't directly related.

author: odyslam
content: TBH I did not know what those notes are. Can anyone creates them?

author: odyslam
content: Yeah, I think scaling and MEV, since the more I read the more I understand how important it can be. The tricky part is what the resources should be

author: odyslam
content: since for exampel, I have read a couple of very well written pieces by Paradigm's blog, which I guess wouldn't be appropriate

author: akh4880
content: Fork the repo, then you can add a notes file then put in a pull request when you want to add it.  Anyone can add them üòÑ

author: odyslam
content: So anyone can create a small personal space to share notes. Interesting

author: odyslam
content: Thanks <@!843901716926955623>  for the context üôÇ
